We study the influence of applying a Fourier transform, denoted as \\(\\mathcal{F}\\), to the initial condition \\(u(x,0)\\) of the system.

If the initial condition \\(u(x,0)\\) is subjected to a Fourier transform to become \\(\\mathcal{F}(u(x,0))\\) and then allowed to evolve under the PDE without additional transformations, will the state of the system \\(u(x,T)\\) at time T be solely determined by the modified initial condition?
Explanation: Transforming the initial condition via Fourier transform alters the mode amplitudes and may shift the phase of components, directly setting a new base state for the solution of the PDE. The system's evolution will follow from this modified state, meaning its state at any time T is determined by this transformed initial condition.
